<@U0UHG4VP1> is it possible to setup a new release build job for V0.6 release build for Power? Previously <@U11HH3P7Y> setup baseimage job at <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric-baseimage/job/fabric-baseimage-release-docker-ppc64le/>

bsmita: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/ci-management> add me as a reviewer
when you have a change
be sure to loop in <@U0KPFAZNF> as well
I am not sure how new requests for builds are done, but is there a sample I can look at?
We don't need baseimage build now, but the build is for peer/membersrvc images
<@U12V3D2P2> "normally" (I say in quotes since this is new plumbing), the -release job runs in response to a maintainer (namely, me) pushing a new git tag to gerrit
a typical flow would be someone, presumably me, submits a dual CR: one that sets IS_RELEASE true, and a second one that resets it back to false along with a bump in the version
it gets voted on: assuming it accumulates at least 2+2 it gets merge
I then create an annotated tag against the commit from the first CR, and push it to gerrit
this triggers jenkins to run the -release job, which, like -verify and -merge will do a full build
the main difference is, this is against the git-tag
if it succeeds, the job also pushes the images out to dockerhub
Ok...the job has to be present in the list right?
since v0.6.1-preview already went through this process (with only x86_64 online) there isnt a natural mechanism to back-release against the same tag
so, assuming the back-release is agreed upon, there are a few options
we could cut a new v0.6 release (like I mentioned, we kind of need to anyway since there are fixes in the branch that didnt make it into v0.6.1)
we could manually trigger the missing builds against the v0.6.1-tag
we could build/push them by hand
im sure there are other options or variations of those same themes
but the main point is: there isnt a turn-key process to accommodate your request: v0.6.1 was already cut
OK..can we do V0.6.2? Along with x86?
I am in favor of this
OK..
Please let me know if I need to do anything for the new release build
are the P builders in Jenkins primed and ready?
The nodes are online, I tried few builds late last week which worked, not sure what needs to be done to cleanup

in the failed jobs listed above (from looking at the console logs), it appears that the make docker target is not defined. 
13:55:00 + make docker
13:55:00 make: *** No rule to make target 'docker'.  Stop.

not sure if this helps, or not...

<@U11MANG9G> since the behave tests are currently disabled/worked around in the fabric build CI process, the following information is not a high priority:

the kafka behave tests utilize x86 docker images ( openjdk:8u111-jre and zookeeper:3.4.9 ) to build the kafka environment.  Both p and z will not be able to run these behave tests.  perhaps down the road, we could incorporate kafka and zookeeper into the fabric-baseimage build process. just a thought.

<@U0UHG4VP1> for those fabric-app-image-verify-docker-* jobs that failed earlier today, it looks like you need to prefix "cd gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric &&" to the "make docker" command listed in the "Execute Shell" portion of the Jenkins job.
it's possible that <@U11HH3P7Y> used the fabric-baseimage jenkins job as a model
in those jobs they just have make docker
I disabled them until someone submits a fix
understand. i could submit a fix, but i'm not sure how i submit a fix for a jenkins job.  if you have any advice, i'd appreciate it.

you would check out the ci-management repo I linked to earlier and do a git log, then look at... two commits from HEAD? three? that's where I disabled them. it will tell you the file to edit and you'll see the pattern
ah ok. cool. thanks!
harrijk look at the second and third commit from HEAD here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/project:ci-management+status:merged>
<@U0UHG4VP1> thanks.
the root issue appears to be in the fabric-macros.yaml file:

- builder:
    name: app-docker-image
    builders:
       - shell: |
          #!/bin/bash -exu
          set -o pipefail

          make docker
make docker should be cd gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric && make docker
i'd like to manually test this in the sandbox
i'll recreate one of the docker app image jobs in the sandbox adding in that additional cd command and see what happens.
